item.title: No Net, No Problem: How I Learned To Love Hurricane Irene | Epicenter | Wired.com
item.description: No Net, No Problem: How I Learned To Love Hurricane Irene: The dynamic might help explain why e-readers work: di... http://t.co/1RcvMgw
item.content:encoded: No Net, No Problem: How I Learned To Love Hurricane Irene: The dynamic might help explain why e-readers work: di... http://t.co/1RcvMgw WESTCHESTER COUNTY, New York – For all the anticipation, Hurricane Irene was a non-event weather-wise here, some 40 miles north of my Wired office in Times Square. But it did usher in the longest power outage I’ve experienced in quite some time. I not only do not have power but I do not have internet: neither of my iPhones (AT&T and Verizon) have voice or data signal to speak of. I am reduced to sometimes texts. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: wired.com

item.title: The Secret Lives of Metal-Detector Hunters | Raw File | Wired.com
item.description: The Secret Lives of Metal-Detector Hunters http://t.co/WOWcOAm
item.content:encoded: The Secret Lives of Metal-Detector Hunters http://t.co/WOWcOAm Though metal-detecting is a solitary pursuit, the hobby can be surprisingly social. Dedicated hunters compete against each other in time trials, searching the beach for pre-seeded targets. Many participate in clubs, where they meet up for show-and-tell and swap war stories about returning lost engagement rings and having close encounters with dog mess. Wired.com recently spent time with some avid beachcombers in the San Francisco Bay Area. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: wired.com
